topic.title: Embedding an Applet in an HTML page

keywords.keyword: Embedding an Applet in an HTML page

para.text: Embedding an Applet in an HTML page
Dolphin Professional or Higher

para.style: text-align:left; text-indent:0px; margin-top:14px; margin-right:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; line-height:1.46; background-color:transparent; white-space:normal; page-break-inside:auto; page-break-after:auto; border:none; tabstops:none;

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: The HTML EMBED tag is used to embed a Dolphin applet within a web page. An EMBED tag has a number of attributes, some of which are essential and some of which can be considered as optional.

para.style: text-align:left; text-indent:0px; margin-top:14px; margin-right:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; line-height:1.46; background-color:transparent; white-space:normal; page-break-inside:auto; page-break-after:auto; border:none; tabstops:none;

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: The following attributes are made use of by the Dolphin
and are required for each instance of an embedded applet.:

The SRC attribute is used to supply a URL that identifies the binary package (.PAK) file containing the applet classes. It is only necessary to specify the package containing the class identified by the APPLET attribute below. Further packages that are prerequisites of this starting package will be automatically located within the same directory.#
This attribute identifies the applet class within the above package. The applet will be started by sending #
showInPlugin
: to this class.

This attribute specifies the MIME type of this EMBED tag. Effectively this identifies the plug-in that will be used to display the applet. To use the Dolphin Web Applet Plug-in (NPDolphin.DLL) this should always be
application/x-dolphin-applet.
The width attribute specifies the pixel width of the area that the web browser will reserve to display the applet.
The height attribute specifies the pixel height of the area that the web browser will reserve to display the applet.

para.style: text-align:left; text-indent:0px; margin-top:14px; margin-right:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; line-height:1.46; background-color:transparent; white-space:normal; page-break-inside:auto; page-break-after:auto; border:none; tabstops:none;

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: The following attributes are optional and can be specified if required:

The NAME attribute can be used to specify a name by which the applet can be referenced. For pages that only load a single applet this is usually not required. However, when multiple applets on a single page are run inside the same plug-in
each applet can reference the others by name.
Normally, the applet class is sent the message #
showInPlugin
: in order to start it. This will automatically use the #
defaultView
resource to display the applet. By using the VIEW attribute it is possible to specify an alternative view resource name to use. If specified, then the applet class will be sent #
show:inPlugin
: when starting.
By default, the plug-in uses a Dolphin image that is supplied as part of
NPDolphin.DLL
to load a binary package and run an applet. By using the IMAGE attribute to specify a full path to an alternative image it is possible to run an applet inside
The PLUGINSPAGE attribute is used to specify a URL that the browser will link to if no appropriate plug-in has been installed for the
application/x-dolphin-applet
MIME type. Usually this page will prompt the user to download and install the Dolphin Web Applet Plug-in. A suitable default page is:
. Although optional, it is normal to include this attribute within all Dolphin applet EMBED tags.
